prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

head.headtext: Criticism of the Policy of Providing Economic Incentives

para.paratext: It has been argued that:

In the real world of largely oligopolistic markets, if the law affords an innovator a head-start protection that enables it to recover a return with profit on its investment, what social interest is there in preventing competitors from imitating the innovator by whatever non-criminal means they devise?[1]

Those who invent, install and market new technologies often do not know how the technologies are going to be used and thus, what the true worth of the information is.[2] In any event, innovation is, in practice, more about improvement than invention, and the development of the invention matters just as much as the original invention.[3] The fact that an owner of goods or services may not realize the monetary value or the effect of the invention on society should not preclude the owner from reaping what he or she has sown. Furthermore, there would seem to be nothing to prevent the person who developed the idea from being compensated independently for the development of the invention (taking into account, of course, the value of the original invention).

It is also argued that the protection of confidential information belonging to individual inventors often results in the censorship of ideas allegedly on equitable or public policy grounds. For instance, Morang & Co. Publishers commissioned the historian Le Sueur to write a history of William Lyon Mackenzie for its Makers of Canada series. Le Sueur obtained copies of Mackenzie's papers from the heirs on the grounds that he was writing for the series. Le Sueur produced a manuscript to the publisher in which he held that Canada came into being despite, rather than because of, Mackenzie's efforts. Mackenzie's heirs convinced the publisher not to publish the work. Not only did the publisher refuse to publish, but it refused to return Le Sueur's manuscript.

Le Sueur was granted the return of his manuscript by the Supreme Court of Canada. However, he was enjoined from publishing it with any publisher since he had obtained access to the papers only on the basis that he would depict Mackenzie as a Maker of Canada. Mackenzie's heirs argued successfully that Le Sueur had broken his implied agreement of confidence.[4]

In Britain, former British secret agent Peter Wright wrote a book called Spycatcher in which he claimed that the British intelligence arm M.I.5 had planned to destabilize the Wilson government and assassinate President Nasser of Egypt. The British government brought actions against Wright in Britain, Eire, Australia, Hong Kong and New Zealand. The actions were based primarily on Wright's breach of confidence to the British government and had nothing to do with whether the allegations were true or not. Although an injunction was refused on appeal after Spycatcher had already been published around the world, the British judges claimed that while many things might be of public interest, it was not necessarily in the public interest that the public know them.

The Le Sueur case had to do with misrepresentation to the owners of the confidential information of the terms of licensing the information. The Spycatcher case demonstrates the dangers of interpreting broad and changing concepts such as the interpretation of public policy. However, although the courts will occasionally make errors in judgment in determining an appropriate balance between the protection and the dissemination of ideas, this does not mean that confidential information should not be protected subject to public policy concerns.

Furthermore, an employee has the right to apply to his or her own best advantage acquired skills and knowledge. This is so even where the knowledge and skill include general processes known to the particular trade. The talent or expertise of employees does not come within the scope of the protection of an employer's confidential business information.[5]

Most nations grant the employee who created a work the status of inventor but vest ownership of the product in the employer. United States copyright law holds that the person or entity employing someone to create the work is not only the copyright owner but also the author of the work. In patent law, also, capitalist states such as Spain and Argentina and former socialist states such as Russia and Yugoslavia, have sometimes allowed corporations to obscure individual innovation and issue patents in the name of the corporation.

Some have argued that restrictive covenants tend to hinder the spread of information that is not confidential business information, and to impinge too broadly on the interest of employees in advancing their own welfare by obtaining the most rewarding jobs possible. In California, post-employment restrictive covenants are unenforceable as a matter of public policy.[6]

There is a further difficulty for both employers and employees in that it is difficult to know in advance of a judicial determination what information is actually able to be protected as confidential business information. It may be that the firm does not even have to allege protection of a “trade secret” in the legal sense; an interest in “confidential information” may suffice.[7]

The question to be determined is not whether restrictive covenants should be enforced, but what constitutes “reasonable justification” as stipulated in the Nordenfelt case.[8] This, as is evidenced by the different application of restrictive covenants by different nations, varies depending on the public policy grounds invoked.
D. Vaver, “What Is a Trade Secret?” in R.T. Hughes, ed., Trade Secrets (Toronto: The Law Society of Upper Canada, 1990), pp. 10-11.
